title: At trial of IS jailers, witnesses recount a totalitarian horror
summary: During the first week of hearings, 11 former hostages testified about the unimaginable abuses they suffered in Syria. Their testimonies also documented the reality of a concentration camp system in which Syrians were the first victims.

title: Israel says Hamas has handed over remains of four hostages
summary: Hamas transferred the bodies of four hostages to the Red Cross early Thursday in exchange for Israel's release of hundreds of Palestinian prisoners, fulfilling the final terms of the ceasefire's first phase. The handover comes just days before the truce is set to expire, as pressure mounts for a second phase of negotiations.

title: Trump says tariff level will be 25% on European Union products
summary: Speaking at a cabinet meeting, Trump described the EU – whose creation was encouraged for decades by Washington – as rooted in an attempt to counter the United States.

title: French court sentences Tunisian man to life in prison for deadly knife attack
summary: Brahim Aouissaoui, 25, admitted he was responsible for killing three people in the 2020 attack at the Basilica of Notre-Dame in the southern city of Nice.

title: France threatens to review longstanding accords with Algeria
summary: The move from French Prime Minister François Bayrou comes after a deadly knife attack in which the main suspect is a man of Algerian origin.

title: A minor revolution in France: Shorts are now allowed in women's gymnastics
summary: At the end of January, the Fédération Française de Gymnastique ruled that women gymnasts may wear shorts over leotards in competitions. The change has been welcomed by many female gymnasts but has also overturned a long-established tradition.

title: 'Like Putin, Trump speaks a language of power that knows no checks and balances'
summary: By attacking the US federal government, the Democratic legacy of the New Deal, and the American social contract, the US president is speaking the same language as his Russian counterpart, observes Le Monde columnist Gilles Paris.

title: 4.4 million Somalis at risk of hunger by June (UN report)
summary: Nearly 4.4 million people in Somalia–23% of the population–will face hunger by June due to worsening drought, high food prices, and ongoing conflict, according to a UN-backed report released Wednesday. The crisis is also expected to leave 1.7 million children under five suffering from acute malnutrition in 2025.

title: Trump says no security promises or NATO for Ukraine
summary: The US president, who has upended US policy by reaching out to Russia and seeking a quick end to the three-year war, will meet with counterpart Volodymyr Zelensky on Friday to seal a deal on handing over natural resources.

title: EU presents emergency competitiveness plan
summary: On Wednesday, February 26, the European Commission presented a number of proposals to support the decarbonization of industry.

title: Tesla stocks plunge, signaling end of markets' Trump euphoria
summary: Elon Musk's company valuation fell below the $1 trillion mark on Tuesday, and its share price is down. While Donald Trump's election had been followed by a surge in the stock market, signs of concern are now emerging.

title: Romania prosecutors indict far-right election candidate
summary: Far-right populist politician and former presidential candidate Calin Georgescu was questioned by Romanian police on Wednesday after the country's constitutional court annulled elections last year.

title: How France has pushed for the release of its citizens held hostage in Gaza
summary: France, which had the second-highest number of victims in the massacre carried out by Hamas on October 7, 2023, has been monitoring the situation in the Middle East closely. The country has supported families and attempted to influence negotiations to secure the release of dual-national hostages.

title: Two French researchers charged over Russian consulate attack
summary: Bottles containing a cocktail of nitrogen and other chemical substances were thrown at the Russian consulate in the port city of Marseille on Monday. No one was injured.

title: Michelle Trachtenberg, 'Buffy the Vampire Slayer' and 'Harriet the Spy' star, dies at 39
summary: The former child star went on to have roles in buzzy millennial-era TV shows. Her cause of death has not yet been announced.

title: French convict 'The Fly' placed in solitary confinement after extradition from Romania
summary: Arrested in Romania and returned to France on Tuesday evening, drug trafficker and fugitive Mohamed Amra has been indicted for 'murder, attempted murder, escape, theft and concealment of theft,' as well as for 'criminal conspiracy.'

title: War in Ukraine: A tangible rapprochement between the US and Russia at the UN
summary: On Monday, the US twice voted with Russia on texts concerning the war in Ukraine, much to the dismay of Kyiv and its European allies.

title: 'Queer': In Mexico, Daniel Craig flees existential loneliness
summary: Adapted from a novel by William S. Burroughs, Luca Guadagnino's film casts the James Bond performer in the role of a drug-addicted American writer in search of love and connection.

title: Since Covid, healthcare workers' disillusionment has only grown: 'We're no more highly regarded now than we were five years ago'
summary: From mid-March to mid-May 2020, at the height of the pandemic, Le Monde kept a 'White Coats Crisis Diary,' with around 20 healthcare workers giving us an inside view of an exceptional health crisis. Five years later, we contacted them again.

title: Trump slashes 90% of USAID contracts, $60 billion in foreign aid
summary: The Trump administration announced Wednesday it is eliminating over 90% of the US Agency for International Development’s foreign aid contracts and cutting $60 billion in global assistance, marking one of the most sweeping rollbacks of US humanitarian and development funding in history.

title: Elon Musk's empire has benefited from $38 billion in contracts and government aid
summary: According to an investigation by 'The Washington Post,' his Tesla and SpaceX companies have been benefiting from large orders and tax credits from local states and the federal government for the past 20 years.

title: After two months of forced closure, Parisian gambing clubs prepare to reopen
summary: Following censure by the Barnier government, these experimental gaming establishments were forced to close on January 1, putting nearly 1,200 employees on partial unemployment. They are set to reopen on February 28 or March 1, still under an experimental status.

title: India sets course for nuclear power
summary: The country, which had been a pioneer in Asia, today generates just 3% of its electricity from nuclear sources. The Modi government wants to change scale, in particular by installing small modular reactors, which could be built on disused coal mines.

title: The 'jogo de bicho,' Brazil's popular clandestine lottery, loses a legendary figure
summary: José Caruzzo Escafura was the best-known of the "bicheiros," the men who rule over the officially illegal but tolerated animal game, which attracts 20 million Brazilians to 350,000 betting points every day.

title: In France's top ski resorts, luxury tourist accommodations are on the rise
summary: In the French Alps's snowiest resorts, high-end new builds rented with luxury hotel services are on the rise, causing adverse effects for locals, seasonal workers and less affluent vacationers.

title: ICC chief backs special tribunal for DR Congo, admits failure to halt atrocities
summary: Decades of atrocities in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo have continued despite international prosecutions, showing the need for a special tribunal, International Criminal Court prosecutor Karim Khan said Wednesday. As violence escalates with Rwanda-backed M23 rebels seizing territory, Khan acknowledged the ICC's limited impact and endorsed Kinshasa's proposal for a new court to deliver justice.

title: Bezos announces restrictions on 'Washington Post' opinion coverage
summary: The move, a major break from the norm at the 'Post' and at most credible news media organizations worldwide, comes as US media face increasing threats to their freedom and accusations of bias from President Donald Trump.

title: French pedophile surgeon's ex-wife 'suspected nothing,' she tells court
summary: Retired surgeon Joël Le Scouarnec, 74, has been on trial in the western city of Vannes since Monday in one of the country's largest child sex abuse cases.

title: Trump administration shatters US financial regulation
summary: The CFPB, the consumer financial protection agency set up in the US after the 2008 crisis, has been particularly targeted. All work there has been frozen by its new director, appointed by the American president. And this is just the beginning.

title: France says it is discussing access to Ukrainian minerals for military use
summary: French Defense Minister Sébastien Lecornu said access to the minerals would not be as payback for France's aid to Ukraine.

title: Ukraine ready to sign agreement with US in hope of appeasing Trump
summary: Volodymyr Zelensky is due to visit Washington on Friday to ask the American president about his support.

title: Actor Gene Hackman, his wife Betsy Arakawa and their dog found dead in home
summary: Local police say that they do not suspect any foul play in the deaths and that an investigation is ongoing.

title: Austria's conservatives will lead new government without far right
summary: The Conservative People's Party, Social Democrats and the liberal Neos will present a 'common program' after deal.

title: War in Ukraine: "A lot of friends are dead, but a lot of friends are pregnant".
summary: Three years after the start of Russia's invasion, the Ukrainian capital shows its wounds as much as its vitality. Although better protected by anti-aircraft defense, the city still experiences drone attacks and power cuts.

title: Attacker gets life sentence for murder of three people at Nice basilica in 2020
summary: Paris's criminal court justified the sentence on the grounds of Brahim Aouissaoui's 'absolute violence,' his lack of 'desire for rehabilitation' and the 'danger' he poses to the public.

title: France's threat of revising migration agreements with Algeria escalates diplomatic row
summary: French Prime Minister François Bayrou announced his government was giving Algiers four to six weeks to accept to repatriate a list of people expelled from France.

title: Macron and Merz meet, keen to revive French-German engine
summary: France has welcomed the future German chancellor's initial positions on defense and Ukraine.

title: The indispensable defense of international aid
summary: Washington's withdrawal from health and food aid programs benefiting the world's poorest populations is all the more troubling as there's no way to compensate for this funding. And yet, this development aid can help reduce the world's problems, from which no country is immune.

title: PKK leader calls on group to drop weapons and disband, in major shift
summary: Abdullah Öcalan called on Thursday for his Kurdish militant group to lay down its weapons and dissolve itself in a declaration drawn up in his cell on Imrali prison island.

title: Andrew Tate, facing human trafficking charges in Romania, leaves for US
summary: Tate and his brother Tristan were headed for Florida on a private jet, their lawyer told CNN on Thursday.
